author: lu_pinto
content:
not sure if the parallel section validation is a valid argument. You can always do parallel sections and then orderly join errors at the end by section number. A bit more complex but it's a valid implementation. Unless you are doing a fail fast approach, which I also prefer, but might also be doable.

Since validation messages don't get leaked on the chain then I agree that it doesn't matter. They could possibly show up in tracing and we would have to decode each of the clients to be sure one is halting for the right reasons, but I'm not convinced this is an enough constraint.

author: lu_pinto
content: But we should keep in mind that depending on which client fills in the tests, you would get slightly different fixtures, which is annoying.

author: racytech
content: I've run some initial benchmarks with parallel validation and results wasn't reasonable. Even thought go's goroutines shouldn't have taken much of resources the benchmarks showed that parallel execution for a relatively small data actually takes up more memory and overall execution time is slower for about  8-10 times

author: _shemnon
content: Even if parallel is not viable, we should be able to handle variable ordering of code section validations. For example, if a client chooses to do sections in reverse or forward order (skipping the work list approach) or even variations in the topoligical sort that section discovery may present.
